[[File:Ferdjohnsonself2.jpg|thumb|Ferd Johnson self-portrait]] '''Ferdinand Johnson''' (December 18, 1905 – October 14, 1996), usually cited as '''Ferd Johnson''', was an American cartoonist, best known for his 68-year stint on the ''[[Moon Mullins]]'' [[comic strip]].
==Biography== Johnson was born December 18, 1905, in [[Spring Creek Township, Warren County, Pennsylvania|Spring Creek, Pennsylvania]],<ref name=syracuse /> and had a younger brother, George.{{citation needed|date=October 2015}} Johnson's youthful interest in cartooning had the support of his family after he won an ''[[Erie Times-News|Erie Dispatch Herald]]'' cartoon contest. He recalled in 1989, "I think I was 11 years old. And then I won a newspaper cartoon drawing contest, and I think the prize was two or three tickets to ''[[Peck's Bad Boy]]'', and that got my dad to thinking, and he gave me a $28 correspondence course. I went through that and worked on the high school yearbook all the time. I did lots of drawings there. At 13, I sold my first cartoon for money to a railroad magazine. It paid me $10 a month for years and years."<ref name=toon-p3>{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1989-09-28/news/li-526_1_comic-strips |page=[http://articles.latimes.com/1989-09-28/news/li-526_1_comic-strips?pg=3 3] |last=McLellan |first=Dennis |title=Toon Talk - Two Comic-Strip Artists Discuss the Craft They Love |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=September 28, 1989 |archivedate=October 13, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cG1JiZP0?url=http://articles.latimes.com/1989-09-28/news/li-526_1_comic-strips |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
After graduating from high school in 1923, he attended the [[School of the Art Institute of Chicago|Chicago Academy of Fine Arts]] for three months.<ref name=syracuse /> When ''[[Moon Mullins]]'' creator [[Frank Willard]] taught briefly there, Willard invited the talented youngster to visit his workplace, ''[[The Chicago Tribune]]''. Johnson recalled, "I stood around there for hours watching him work. He finally turned around and said, 'Ferd, if you're going to hang around here all this time, I'm going to put you to work.' So I got a job as assistant at 15 bucks a week. I wrote home, and I said, 'Don't send me any more money. I've got it made."<ref name=toon-p2>McLellan, [http://articles.latimes.com/1989-09-28/news/li-526_1_comic-strips/2 p. 2]</ref> Dropping out of school, he became Willard assistant two months after Willard launched ''Moon Mullins'' in 1923.<ref name=syracuse>{{cite web |url=http://library.syr.edu/digital/guides/j/johnson_f.htm |title=Ferd Johnson Cartoons > Biographical History |publisher=[[Syracuse University]] Special Collections |accessdate=October 13, 2015 |archivedate=October 13, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6cG1jUgCZ?url=http://library.syr.edu/digital/guides/j/johnson_f.htm |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Johnson worked at the ''Tribune'' as a color artist and sports illustrator.
While Johnson was still in his teens, the paper offered him the opportunity to create his own comic strip. Johnson's effort, ''Texas Slim'', about a ranch hand working for the antihero Dirty Dalton, debuted as a [[Sunday strip|Sunday page]] from the [[Tribune Media Services|Tribune Syndicate]] on August 30, 1925. It ran three years. In 1932, Johnson revived ''Texas Slim'' as a [[Comic strip#Sunday comics|topper strip]] paired with his short-lived domestic-comedy strip ''Lovey Dovey''. On March 31, 1940, the characters returned once again as a Sunday strip titled ''Texas Slim & Dirty Dalton'', which ran through 1958.<ref name=toonopedia>[http://toonopedia.com/texaslim.htm ''Texas Slim''] at [[Don Markstein's Toonopedia]]. [https://www.webcitation.org/6cFzEHPhV?url=http://toonopedia.com/texaslim.htm Archived] from the original on October 13, 2015.</ref>
Willard and Johnson traveled to Florida, Maine and Los Angeles, doing the strip while living in hotels, apartments and farmhouses. At its peak of popularity during the 1940s and 1950s, the strip ran in 350 newspapers. According to Johnson, he had been doing the strip solo for at least a decade before Willard's death on January 11, 1958. "They put my name on it then", Johnson said in 1989. "I had been doing it about 10 years before that because Willard had heart attacks and strokes and all that stuff. The minute my name went on that thing and his name went off, 25 papers dropped the strip. That shows you that, although I had been doing it 10 years, the name means a lot."<ref name=toon-p3 />
After Willard's death, the [[Tribune Media Services|Chicago Tribune New York News Syndicate]] hired Johnson as Willard's logical successor, and he began signing the strip. Johnson recalled that, ''''Texas [Slim & Dirty Dalton]'' ran until 1958 when I took over ''Moon'' completely. Up to then I was working on both ''Moon'' and ''Texas'' and some advertising work, and taking some time off to eat and sleep."<ref>[http://www.reuben.org/members2.html National Cartoonists Society] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091125094703/http://www.reuben.org/members2.html |date=2009-11-25 }}</ref>
He stayed with the strip until it concluded in 1991.<ref name=syracuse /> In 1978,{{citation needed|date=October 2015}} his son, Tom Johnson, signed on as his assistant<ref name=syracuse /> (drawing the Sunday page and assisting on the dailies).{{citation needed|date=October 2015}} Ferd Johnson worked on ''Moon Mullins'' for 68 years, a stint that comics historian [[Don Markstein]] calls "probably the longest in the history of American comics."<ref name=toonopedia />
Johnson continued to draw and paint after he moved into a retirement home in [[Irvine, California]] in 1995,{{citation needed|date=October 2015}} and he died 15 months later.{{citation needed|date=October 2015}} Doris, his wife of 57 years, whom he met in art school in Chicago, died in 1986.{{citation needed|date=October 2015}}
==Awards== Ferd Johnson received a ComicCon International Inkpot Award in 1993.<ref>[http://www.comic-con.org/cci/cci_inkpot.shtml#J ComicCon International Inkpot Awards] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091229183151/http://www.comic-con.org/cci/cci_inkpot.shtml |date=2009-12-29 }}</ref>
